proof:
According to Lemmas 33 and 34, with high probability, any vertex set in $G$ of size at least $\eta n$ has an average degree of at least $3d/4$. Furthermore, one of these lemmas also establishes that, with high probability, any vertex set $S \subseteq V_G$ whose size is between $\eta n$ and $(1-\eta)n$ satisfies the inequality $|E_G(S,S)| \ge \frac{5d}{6}|S|(n-|S|)$. With high probability, it also holds that $n_C \ge (1-e^{-d/3})n$. For the remainder of the proof, we will assume that the graph $G$ satisfies all of these properties.

Based on our choice of $\eta$ and by Lemma 12, it holds with high probability that for any given configuration $F \in \Omega_C^{\text{ord}}$, the graph $(V_C, F)$ contains a giant component with a total degree of at least $\frac{9}{10}\text{degg}(V_C)$. Consequently, if we define $S$ as the set of vertices belonging to the non-giant components, the total degree of $S$ is at most $\frac{1}{10}\text{degg}(V_C)$. We should note that any edge in $E_G(S,S)$ must belong to the set $E_C \setminus F$. We proceed by considering three distinct cases based on the size of the set $S$.

First, suppose that $|S| \ge \frac{n}{2}$. In this case, the total degree of $S$ must be greater than $\frac{dn}{4}$. However, we also know that $\text{degg}(S) \le \frac{\text{degg}(V_C)}{10}$, which is less than $\frac{dn}{10}+o(n)$. These two bounds on $\text{degg}(S)$ contradict each other.

Second, let's consider the case where $\eta n \le |S| \le \frac{n}{2}$. This implies that $|E_C \setminus F| \ge |E_G(S,S)| \ge \frac{5\eta nd}{12}$. With high probability, however, we have $|E_C| \le \frac{dn}{2}+o(n) < \frac{3dn}{4}$, which leads to a contradiction with the property that $|E_C \setminus F| \le \eta|E_C|$.

Therefore, the only remaining possibility is that $|S| \le \eta n$. In this situation, the number of components $c(F)$ is bounded by $|S|$, which is at most $\eta n + 1$. Additionally, the number of edges $|F|$ is less than $|E_C|$, which with high probability is at most $nd/2+\eta n$. As a result, we can bound the weight $w_C(F)$, obtaining $w_C(F) < q^{\eta n+1}(e^\beta - 1)^{nd/2+\eta n}$. This is in turn strictly less than $q^{\eta n+2-1/10 \cdot nd/d+\eta n}$, an expression that is equal to $q^{n[1-1/20+2\eta]}$.

Considering that the empty set $\emptyset$ is a configuration with weight $q^{n_C} > q^{n(1-e^{-d/3})}$, it follows that the partition function $Z_C$ must be greater than $q^{n-ne^{-d/3}}$. The total number of ordered configurations is at most $2^{|E_C|} = 2^{nd/2+\eta n}$, which allows us to bound the ratio $\frac{Z_C^{\text{dis}}}{Z_C}$ as follows:
$$ \frac{Z_C^{\text{dis}}}{Z_C} < 2^{nd/2+\eta n}q^{n[\eta-1+1-1/10+2\eta+e^{-d/3}]} = \exp\{n[d\ln 2/2 + \log q(-1/10+2\eta+e^{-d/3})]\}. $$
For a sufficiently large value of $d$, the inequality $1/10 - 2\eta - e^{-d/3} > 1/20$ is satisfied. Consequently, the expression above is bounded by $\exp\{nd \ln 2/2 - n \log q/20\}$. For a sufficiently large value of $q$, this final term is less than or equal to $e^{-n}$.
